head.title: Does Reunification Begin at the Mall?

hedline.hl1: Does Reunification Begin at the Mall?

abstract.p: Vincent Wei-cheng Wang letter says orchestrated shopping tours of North and South Koreans (Aug 17 article) could accelerate process of reunification; map

block.p: Re ''Like It or Not, North Koreans Tour a Mall in Seoul'' (news article, Aug. 17): If both North and South Koreans are convinced of the potential of orchestrated reunions and shopping tours for reunification, they need to remember what happened to East Germany.

In 1989, East Germany's last Communist leader, Egon Krenz, gambled that by allowing his people to visit West Germany, he could delay unification. His logic: after collecting the 100-mark allowance given by West Germany and shopping at the stores on Kurfurstendamm, East Germans would return home.

Re ''Like It or Not, North Koreans Tour a Mall in Seoul'' (news article, Aug. 17): If both North and South Koreans are convinced of the potential of orchestrated reunions and shopping tours for reunification, they need to remember what happened to East Germany.

In 1989, East Germany's last Communist leader, Egon Krenz, gambled that by allowing his people to visit West Germany, he could delay unification. His logic: after collecting the 100-mark allowance given by West Germany and shopping at the stores on Kurfurstendamm, East Germans would return home.
Letting East Germans travel could dissuade West Germans who feared a potential refugee crisis. Of course, his plan failed miserably and Germany was unified sooner than many had expected.
South Korea and its allies should start preparing. They may get what they wish, except too soon.
VINCENT WEI-CHENG WANG Richmond, Va., Aug. 17, 2000
The writer is a political science professor, University of Richmond.
